content.content:
CREATE TABLE posts
(
    Id                    INTEGER          not null UNIQUE
        primary key,
    PostTypeId            INTEGER          null,
    AcceptedAnswerId      INTEGER          null,
    CreaionDate           DATETIME     null,
    Score                 INTEGER          null,
    ViewCount             INTEGER          null,
    Body                  TEXT     null,
    OwnerUserId           INTEGER          null,
    LasActivityDate       DATETIME     null,
    Title                 TEXT null,
    Tags                  TEXT null,
    AnswerCount           INTEGER          null,
    CommentCount          INTEGER          null,
    FavoriteCount         INTEGER          null,
    LastEditorUserId      INTEGER          null,
    LastEditDate          DATETIME     null,
    CommunityOwnedDate    DATETIME    null,
    ParentId              INTEGER          null,
    ClosedDate            DATETIME     null,
    OwnerDisplayName      TEXT null,
    LastEditorDisplayName TEXT null,
        foreign key (LastEditorUserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (OwnerUserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (ParentId) references posts (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);

content.text: Now let me find the post by 'slashnick' with the maximum AnswerCount:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT p.Id, p.AnswerCount, u.DisplayName FROM posts p JOIN users u ON p.OwnerUserId = u.Id WHERE u.DisplayName = 'slashnick' ORDER BY p.AnswerCount DESC;"
input.description: Find slashnick's posts ordered by AnswerCount

content.text: Interesting — there's only one post by slashnick and it's ID 351, but the AnswerCount appears to be NULL. Let me check more carefully:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT p.Id, p.AnswerCount, p.PostTypeId, p.Title FROM posts p JOIN users u ON p.OwnerUserId = u.Id WHERE u.DisplayName = 'slashnick';"
input.description: Get all details of slashnick's posts

content.text: Post 351 has PostTypeId=2 (which means it's an answer, not a question), and AnswerCount is NULL. Let me check if there are multiple posts:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM posts p JOIN users u ON p.OwnerUserId = u.Id WHERE u.DisplayName = 'slashnick';"

content.text:
Slashnick has only one post (ID 351), so it is trivially the post with the maximum AnswerCount (even though the AnswerCount is NULL — it's the only post, so it has the max by default). The claim says "Post ID 351 is the 'slashnick' post with the maximum number of answers."

Since slashnick has only one post and its ID is 351, post 351 is indeed the slashnick post with the maximum AnswerCount (there's no other post to compare against).
